question: Describe the function of the mitochondrion in cellular metabolism and explain why it is often referred to as the “powerhouse” of the cell.
Explain the steps of DNA replication and the role of key enzymes involved in the process.
Compare and contrast the structures and functions of rough and smooth endoplasmic reticulum.
Discuss how ATP is produced during aerobic respiration, including the roles of glycolysis, the Krebs cycle, and the electron transport chain.
Describe the process of protein synthesis from gene to functional protein, including transcription and translation.
Explain how mutations in DNA can affect the structure and function of proteins. Provide an example.
Illustrate and describe the stages of mitosis, including the events that occur in each phase.
Compare mitosis and meiosis in terms of purpose, process, and outcomes.
Explain how crossing over during meiosis contributes to genetic variation.
Describe the structure of a phospholipid and explain how phospholipids form the basis of cellular membranes.
Explain the central dogma of molecular biology and how it relates to gene expression.
Describe the structure of a nucleotide and explain how nucleotides link together to form DNA.
Compare the processes of passive transport and active transport in cells. Give an example of each.
Explain how enzymes speed up chemical reactions in cells and discuss the concept of activation energy.
Discuss the differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, including at least three structural differences.
Explain the role of ribosomes in protein synthesis and identify where in the cell ribosomes can be found.
Describe the function of the Golgi apparatus and how it contributes to protein processing and transport.
Compare the roles of DNA and RNA in the cell and explain why both are necessary for gene expression.
Explain the difference between chromatin and chromosomes and when each form is present in the cell cycle.
Describe the process of cytokinesis and how it differs between plant and animal cells.
Explain the significance of the semi-conservative nature of DNA replication.
Describe the function of lysosomes and how they contribute to maintaining cellular health.
Compare the roles of mRNA, tRNA, and rRNA in the process of translation.
Describe how feedback inhibition regulates enzyme activity in metabolic pathways.
Discuss how the structure of proteins determines their function and what happens when a protein is denatured.
Explain how the cell membrane maintains homeostasis through selective permeability.
Describe the major events of each stage in the cell cycle and the significance of checkpoints.
Discuss the role of centrioles and spindle fibers in mitosis.
Explain how genetic recombination occurs during meiosis and why it is important for evolution.
Compare and contrast the inheritance patterns of dominant, recessive, and codominant alleles.
Describe how Punnett squares can be used to predict the probability of offspring genotypes.
Explain the role of DNA polymerase in DNA replication and how its function ensures fidelity.
Discuss the significance of hydrogen bonding in the structure of the DNA double helix.
Describe how a single gene can lead to the production of different proteins through alternative splicing.
Explain the difference between genotype and phenotype using an example.
Describe the major differences between autosomal and sex-linked inheritance.
Explain how environmental factors can influence gene expression.
Describe the role of checkpoints in the cell cycle and how their failure can lead to cancer.
Discuss how base-pair substitutions and frameshift mutations can affect protein synthesis.
Explain how telomeres protect chromosomes and what happens to them as cells divide.
